docs.lead_paragraph: After giving ground on welfare, Medicaid and several other issues important to moderate Republicans and the White House, the Senate early today followed the lead of the House and approved a bill designed to balance the Federal budget by 2002. Included in the bill are provisions that would cut taxes by $245 billion and turn over to the states much more responsibility to care for the country's poor.

headline.main: SENATE SOFTENS SOME EDGES IN PASSING, 52-47, ITS VERSION OF VAST BUDGET CUTBACKS

docs.lead_paragraph: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company said today that third-quarter earnings from operations rose 42 percent on reduced costs for pollution cleanup and catastrophe damage. The company, the largest publicly traded American life insurer, said its earnings, excluding losses from the sale of investments, rose to $212.6 million, or $1.86 a share, from $149.6 million, or $1.33 a share, in the corresponding period a year earlier. That result exceeded the expectations of $1.67 a share of 18 analysts surveyed by Zacks Investment Research.

docs.lead_paragraph: If messing with Social Security is like touching the third rail of American politics, as Speaker Thomas J. O'Neill Jr. used to say, then tinkering with Medicare is like throwing yourself in front of the train. Republicans are being reminded of it every day.

headline.main: Of Touching Third Rails And Tackling Medicare
headline.kicker: BATTLE OVER THE BUDGET: THE STRATEGY

docs.lead_paragraph: The House of Representatives today approved the foundation of the Republican revolution: a mammoth bill that would balance the Federal budget in seven years, cut the taxes of most families and significantly diminish the place of the Federal Government in the lives of Americans. President Clinton has vowed to veto the legislation, so it will be weeks before it is known how many of its elements will become law. But its approval today underscored the willingness of the members of the new Republican majority to cast difficult votes in areas that have proved politically risky in the past.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Regarding Medicare "reform," no one seems to be addressing the drastic difference between a 65-year-old and an 85-year-old. At 65 years my father was still working as a physician and my parents were traveling and leading an active social life. Twenty years later my father is deceased and my mother resides in a nursing home, wheelchair-ridden and with severe dementia.

docs.lead_paragraph: The income gap between rich and poor was wider in the United States during the 1980's than in any other large industrialized country, according to the most comprehensive international study ever released on income distribution. Britain, France, Italy and Ireland all had highly paid elites, but the gap between high-paid and low-paid Americans was wider in the mid-1980's than in these countries or in a dozen others included in the study, which was commissioned by the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, a Paris-based group that aims to coordinate the economic policies of the world's 25 richest nations.

docs.lead_paragraph: As Republicans in Congress continue to make great progress in their mission to dismantle the Medicare and Medicaid programs, keep in mind that this odious effort has nothing to do with any desire to reform the health-care system, or to improve the quality of services available to the poor, the elderly, the young or the disabled. The suffering of real people is not a concern of politicians whose moral universe is represented in its totality by the dollar sign. The assault on Medicare and Medicaid is, purely and simply, a naked grab for hundreds of billions of dollars earmarked for the care of people unfortunate enough to have fallen ill.

docs.lead_paragraph: When an elderly person breaks a hip, the typical hospital stay is just seven days. That is at least three fewer days than was the case a decade ago, before Medicare switched to a flat payment system for each illness or injury. But while the payment system was meant to cap Medicare spending, it wound up doing the reverse. Because such patients are hardly ready to dance home after a week, they are transferred to nursing homes for follow-up care. Medicare pays again, often at $400 a day, and it may pay later for therapy in the patient's home. "The Government ended up paying at least twice," said Kenneth S. Abramowitz, a health care securities analyst with Sanford C. Berstein & Company.
